dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man on fire, his face and hair aflame. He stares at you accusation in his eyes. You raise a hand to keep him away The hand bursts into flame. It is a torch, skin blisterin The burning man screams. You are inside a tank, M1A1 Abra The instruments glow green. Another man on fire scrambles from the hatch. The fire traces a lazy line across the bulkhead. It is headed to the ammunition stacks. The man screams at you again. The fire leaps upon the magazine of 20mm shells. It dances there a few seconds. The man is upon you - burning before your eyes. The scream is intelligible for the first time. "I DON'T WANT TO DIE!"

dialogues.speaker: INT. BAR, DAY
dialogues.text: The flames become amber fluid in glass. COLONEL NATHANIAL "NAT" SERLING, looks at the glass, at h watch, finishes the drink, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BAR, DAY
dialogues.text: Serling crosses the street pouring half a box of Tic-Tacs into his mouth, eating them like candy. He heads toward one of those anonymous buildings in Suitl outside Washington, D.C. Serling is in his 40's, born to uniform, but there is something sad in his eyes, defeated his walk. He enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY, DAY
dialogues.text: The sign on a door says "U.S. Army - Awards and Decoratio Branch." Serling enters.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COLONEL LEVINE'S OFFICE, DAY
dialogues.text: COLONEL PHILLIP LEVINE, a little martinet, a bureaucratic Hitler. Serling sits across from the desk from Levine. The desk i immaculate, everything arranged with a ruler and a T-squa Nameplate with pens up front.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 2.

dialogues.speaker: LEVINE
dialogues.text: I remember you. I was there in Desert Storm, 24th Mech. Serling nods grimly. He's been through this before. Levin won't let it alone.

dialogues.speaker: LEVINE
dialogues.text: Frankly, I'm surprised you're still in the service.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: So am I. The answer doesn't give Levine any satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: LEVINE
dialogues.text: I don't agree with this assignment. I'm sure the General has his own reasons.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I'm sure. Could I look at the file? The file sits alone on that splendid desk - centered.

dialogues.speaker: LEVINE
dialogues.text: I'm not required to release the documentation until I receive all of the proper forms and orders. He smiles. What a paper-pushing asshole. Serling smiles ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: LEVINE
dialogues.text: Something funny, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Just petty little men like you who don't have power but pounce on any semblance of it like a crow ona road kill. Levine clenches his jaw. He's about to reply or spit. The door opens. GENERAL HERSHBERG enters. The two Colonels stand at attention until the General nod then down. He slides his butt onto Levine's desk, sweepin the nameplate to the corner. Levine has a shitfit, but swallows it.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. HERSHBERG
dialogues.text: How are you doing, Nat?  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 3. Hershberg

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I have an "In" box and an "Out." I empty one and fill the other. I even have a rubber stamp with my name on it so I don't get writer's cramp. It's heaven. picks up the file, glances at the label and tosses it to Serling. Levine is about to protest, but a look fro the General cuts it off at the knees. Hershberg He rises.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. HERSHBERG
dialogues.text: This is a little hot potato and in that weird form of Washington alchemy it could turn into a political football. Captain Karen Emma Walden, first woman to be eligible for the Medal of Honor.

dialogues.speaker: LEVINE
dialogues.text: In combat.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. HERSHBERG
dialogues.text: In combat. First we got all the stink about women in combat. There are some who will be sniping at this just because of that. Then there are those that are going to line up and say we're only doing this to overcompensate or distract the public from the charges of sexism and sexual harassment in the services.

dialogues.speaker: LEVINE
dialogues.text: Bullshit. looks at Levine like he was a cockroach on a cake.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. HERSHBERG
dialogues.text: There are only two things you have to worry about, Nat. The President wants this. I want this. His reasons ... ? As usual I haven't a clue. I want it because I think she deserves it. Put it under a microscope. With your usual thoroughness, Nat. Any problems call my Adjutant, Captain Banachek, or even me. No Slacking. This is important, Nat. To the nation. To the Army. To me. Let's go. Levine pops up.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 4.

dialogues.speaker: LEVINE
dialogues.text: Sir, I can't let that file leave this office. I haven't received my 2930 or the 264.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. HERSHBERG
dialogues.text: Colonel, there's nothing I detest more than little D.C. hamsters who can't see beyond the paper at the bottom of their little cages. He leads Serling out, closes the door behind him. Levine left to straighten his desk.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BUILDING, DAY
dialogues.text: The General's car waits outside. Hershberg and Serling ex go to the car. Hershberg looks up at the building.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. HERSHBERG
dialogues.text: That's what's killing this country. Not crime or pollution. My daddy used to tell me -- look close at the word bureaucrat. There's always a rat in it. (beat) Do this right, Nat, and you can broom your rubber stamps.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. HERSHBERG
dialogues.text: Captain Banachek has a list of the eyewitnesses and their current postings. Need a ride?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: No, sir. I drove my own car.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. HERSHBERG
dialogues.text: Well, don't blow through a stop sign. That breath will lose you your license. Serling is embarrassed. He salutes. Hershberg salutes bac and gets into the car, unwinds the window.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. HERSHBERG
dialogues.text: Do this right, Nat, Captain Karen Walden deserves it. And you need it.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 5. And he signals to the driver and is gone. Serling looks at the file, walks to his car, stops. He ma a right turn, crosses the street, enters a bar.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RESIDENTIAL STREET, DAY
dialogues.text: A big house and a big yard. There are five kids in the ya with a refrigerator box. They are arguing over the benefi of creating a house or a fort. A lot of yelling, laughing and running back and forth to the house for scissors, fat felt pens and a hacksaw blade to cut the windows or gun p (still under heated discussion). Serling watches from his car, parked across the street. A woman comes out of the house. She is handsome, some of the kids look like her. Her name is MEREDITH. She carries a steaming cup of coffee and walks in a straight path acr the street to Serling.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Just made a fresh pot. I put some cocoa in it for you.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Thanks. You got a new fridge.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Yes. The noise it used to make at three in the morning? That horrible rattle and moan? Didn't make it night before last. She leans comfortably against the car.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Got up to find a big puddle on the kitchen floor and had to throw away a whole chicken. This one's more efficient and has an ice maker in the door. (beat) You can't do this anymore. It scares the kids. Serling notices the children glancing his way.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: They don't understand why their daddy chose to move out and leave them. Neither do I.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: You don't? I explained it to you. I have to work out this ... thing.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I hear what you say. That doesn't mean I understand it. But the kids. They think it's their fault. Don't do this to them anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I... I'm leaving town for a days. Hershberg's got me taking a Medal of Honor and wrapping it up ina shiny wrapper.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Medal of Honor?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: A woman.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Good for her.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Posthumous.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Too bad. But still good for her. And about time. How long you goin to be gone?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: A week. Ten days.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: When you get back we have to deal with this. One way or another. She makes it sound very ominous. Serling makes light, Smi

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Sounds like an ultimatum. She doesn't smile at all.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: It is. I don't want you haunting us like this. Either you come through that front door -- to stay -- or you don't come back here at all. That was hard to say.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 7. And she walks back to the house, trying to hold onto her composure, tears he can't see in her eyes. But Serling ca feel them. He knows her that well. He holds the cup up to her. It is empty. The front door slams shut. Serling drives away. All five kids stop and watch him go.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLANE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: It is dark in the plane. Most overhead lights out, most passengers sleeping. One light is on -- Serling's. He is in civilian clothes. There is a collection of little bottles on Serling's tray all empty. He is reading Walden's file. There are tears in his eyes. The stewardess comes by and sees the tears. Serling, embarrassed, turns off the overhead light and turns his f to the window. He can see his own reflection. A man in pain. Deep, soul-cutting pain. He pulls down the shade.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FORT BRAGG, DAY
dialogues.text: Fort Bragg, North Carolina. Home of the 82nd Airborne. Serling, in uniform, walks into one of those one-story wo barracks left over from WII.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BARRACKS, DAY
dialogues.text: A classroom. Horrible photos of the results of bad dental hygiene, an illustration of proper brushing. Serling turn the disgusting photos to face the wall. The room is filli up with eleven men, all talking excitedly. It is a reunio of sorts. Hugs, unashamed tears and endless talk. "What have you been doing?" "Going to meet with us after?" "You getting fat, man." A man in civilian clothes enters and is instantly surroun by the others. "Where you been?" "How's civilian life?" "How are the legs?" He pulls up his pant legs to reveal two artificial limbs. That brings a round of scar comparison as clothing is pee away or dropped to reveal the shiny tissue. War wounds. Serling watches -- an outsider.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 8. FIRST LIEUTENANT CHELLI counts heads and goes up to Serli

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: All present and accounted for, sir. Serling faces the men as they settle into their seats.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I'm trying to confirm the sequence of events that occurred at or around Al Kufan on 26 February 1991. How did you men come to be on the Blackhawk designated Dust Off Two piloted by Warrant officer Fowler? Was it a combat Medevac?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: No. Sir. Traffic accident.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: Damn Saudi drivers, sir. Thought they were driving cabs in New York.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Most of them are.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: We'd have a convoy of thirty trucks or more and they'd decide to pass.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: And another Kamikazi Saudi would be coming the other way.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: They couldn't go to the shoulder -- minefields. They'd...

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: We were heading along the north end of Iraq to set up a fueling depot for the 24th, part of Schwartzkopf's "Hail Mary". Some mad Saudi in a deuce-and-a-half goes to pass the convoy and suddenly there's another convoy coming the other way.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 9.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD, DAY
dialogues.text: A long column of trucks roll down a narrow road. Smoke fr Kuwait wafts over the endless sand. In the back of one fi ton truck 2nd Lt. Chelli and his men, plus ten more, sit, bored, smoking and joking. A Saudi driver in a big pale blue piece of shit truck thu down the road passing the Army convoy, oblivious to the danger, bouncing his head to some Paul Revere and the Rai music. Then he sees the other convoy. He looks for a gap in the traffic alongside of him. None. He slams on the brakes! The truck goes into a skid. It fishtails, ramming Chelli's truck. The trucks hurtle off the road. Both hit mines on the shoulder. The Saudi truck blows up. The big five-ton flips onto its side and skids for yards, plowing sand. Another mine goes off. The truck stops. The passengers litter the sand, wounded -- moaning, screaming bleeding or very still.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLT
dialogues.text: We had fifteen injured. Mostly broken bones, contusions.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: A few burns. The Saudi truck blew up.

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS
dialogues.text: Mines were going off like popcorn, but no shrapnel wounds.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: The Saudi truck burned. The driver was a crispy critter.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: His cargo was all over the road. Pampers and shower shoes -- flip flops, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS
dialogues.text: Here we are running around scared shitless of poison gas, and Scuds and the damn Republican Guard and we get taken out by some Saudi speed merchant with a truck load of flip flops.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 10.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: The Medevac, Warrant officer Fowler's bird, picked us up and headed south to some MASH unit. Nothing happened on the trip. It was pretty routine.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: Until we were shot down. That statement takes the wind out of everybody.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BLACKHAWK, DAY
dialogues.text: The Blackhawk flies low along the east side of the Euphra River. Mountains on both sides. Inside are Lt. Chelli and his men, bandaged and bloodied but conscious.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Altitude?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Low, fifty to a hundred feet off the floor. The chopper shudders. A huge impact. Then it begins to fall. Shouting, screaming. The chopper hits the ground hard. The impact splays the skids. Men fall out the doors

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Do you know what brought you down?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: No. Triple A, a missile, TOW? Couldn't tell. One moment we were up -- the next we were eating sand.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: When did you see the enemy?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: Egan thought he saw some enemy movement before we got hit.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: Just some figures below. Could have been Bedouins, hard to tell.

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS
dialogues.text: I thought I saw a flash.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 11.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Firearms.

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS
dialogues.text: Small arms. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: I didn't see anything.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: The pilot and co-pilot were killed on impact?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: Yes. The medic, Balkum? Balkum, confirmed this. The Blackhawk nosed into the mountain. The Medic and Crew Chief started giving aid to the new injuries. We lost two immediately, Feretic, and Brady. Another, Rizza, died a few minutes later. My Platoon Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: The Crew Chief tried to get out an SOS. The pilot didn't have time... He wasn't able to raise anyone, the radio was wasted in the crash.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: How long before you saw the enemy?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: About an hour - a little more. Ground troops. They came over the ridge to the northwest of us. They fired on us.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: All we had was the Crew Chief's M- 16 and four nine mills, the chopper crew's side arms.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: They stripped us of our weapons on the Medevac. Procedure. The Crew Chief returned fire with his 16. We were downslope.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: Sitting ducks.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 12.

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS
dialogues.text: But the Crew Chief kept the enemy to the ridge. Until 1600 hours Â» around there.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: When he was hit.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: Yes. He was on his last magazine. The nine mills didn't have the range. Rounds fell short.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Any of the enemy fire prove to be effective?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: Monaco took two in the chest. He died during the night. Lem, Fistch were wounded. Cherensky, no he was later.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: And you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: Yes. I took a round in the leg. And the medic had a bullet part his hair. A lot of blood but he was still working.

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS
dialogues.text: The chopper provided us no cover. Bullets went through it like cardboard.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: We were in a world of hurt, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Did you discuss surrendering? Lt. Chelli looks at the others.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. We were all wounded in one way or another. It was discussed. But we figured we'd hold 'em off as long as possible in case a rescue came. It was a . difficult and protracted debate, sir.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 13.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I suspect so.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: We weren't trained for that kinda shit.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Then the tank appeared.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BLACKHAWK, DAY
dialogues.text: The men in the crashed chopper are in rough shape. Batter bloody, the dead covered with a poncho that flaps in the wind. SWOCK! Gunfire and another hole in the fuselage. The body of the chopper looks like Swiss cheese.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We'd been there a few hours. Our shit was pretty flaky by then. The Medic, head bandaged, returns fire sparingly. Thena noise. Everyone listens, even the most gravely wounded. They all try to see. Over the river, up the slope and acr the ridge. The sound comes from there. And over the crest of the ridge appears a tank. A Russian T-55. It pauses at the ridge. Then with a clatter and roar, comes up over th ridge and to the down slope. It stops. Then the turret swivels. Until the gun-points at the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's a very strange feeling to be sitting there and watch a big gun like that make adjustments to blow you away. And the gun does that, with whirrs and cranks. A little elevation. A little windage. Then ... BOOM! The gun fires The tank jerks back. The tail section of the helicopter disintegrates! There is a huge cloud of dust in front of the tank, thrown up by the concussion. With little wind i just hangs there, dissipating slowly.

dialogues.speaker: JR. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: All we could do was wait until the dust settled so they could see to adjust. That's when, as ranking officer, I made my decision.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 14. The Lieutenant steps out of the helicopter, waving his wh handkerchief. He takes a couple of steps toward the tank.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I figured we'd held out as long as we could and that the lives of the men on board...

dialogues.speaker: SERLING, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You don't have to make excuses for your actions to me, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I know, sir, I know. It's just... Well, it didn't make any difference. The cloud of dust finally settles in front of the tank. They can see Chelli and the white flag of surrender. And the tank machine gun cuts loose. The Lieutenant is hit in his good leg. He goes down. Two men, wounded themselves, run and haul him back to the chopper. The tank's big gun begins to move again in small increments.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We were just target practice for their big gun.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A turkey shoot. It fires! BOOM! This one misses - too far off the nose of the chopper.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now they had us bracketed. All they had to do was adjust for somewhere in the middle and we were dead meat. The Medic fires at the tank with the M-16. The rounds jus bounce off. Lt. Chelli stops him and looks up at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And then we heard it.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There's something about an inbound Huey... And suddenly up the river comes an American Huey helicopt The unmistakable red cross of Medevac on its side.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 15. It buzzes by the downed Blackhawk and tank then does a st U-turn and comes back.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did it take any ground fire?

dialogues.speaker: EGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Right off the bat.

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Instantly, every rag head ground pounder wanted a piece of that bird. The enemy troops fire at the chopper, but the only real indication are the tracers arcing through the sky.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When the Huey cans back this time it returned fire. Someone with a 240.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That Monfriez guy.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We didn't know at the time but.. yes, SP/5 Monfriez. The ground troops went for cover. The men in the Blackhawk cheer. Elation takes them past t pain of their wounds. BOOM! The tank fires again. The men in the Blackhawk are blown to bits.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That round killed the Medic, Raleno, Cerspach... Egan lost his legs.... Chaos. Men dying, bleeding, screaming - praying.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We tended the wounded as best we could.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And waited for the next round to hit.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What was the Huey doing at this time?  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 16.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It circled back to go over the tank again.

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then they threw something overboard at the tank. The Huey banks and over the tank, a dark square object plummets out the open door and lands a few yards away. Th Huey bucks and turns. One of the wounded men directs the Lieutenant's attention to the chopper.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Threw or it fell off?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Couldn't tell the first time. But the chopper banked and we could see the Crew Chief unstrapping something from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: The fuel pod. He was unhooking it. I knew. I used to work choppers at Fort Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They were still taking ground fire. We could see where the tank's big machine gun was making hits. But the Huey banked again and this time the fuel pod hit.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: Dead hit. It burst like a water balloon.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: JP8 - air fuel all over the tank.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then someone in the Huey fired a flare at the tank. And it blew. The tank is drenched in gas. The tank commander, sitting half in, half out of the turret is yelling commands when realizes what is going on. He tries to bail. Too late. The tank erupts in flames. The ground troops run away from the burning tank. KA-BOOM! Something goes off inside the tank. Then another explosion, and another. The ammo inside cooks and blows.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 17. The tank disintegrates. Inside the crashed Blackhawk, the men cheer.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BARRACKS, DAY
dialogues.text: The men relive that moment with smiles and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Did you see what knocked the Huey down? The mood darkens.

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIVER, DAY
dialogues.text: Inside the Blackhawk the mood darkens as they see the Hue

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We were yelling and screaming so much we didn't notice the Huey was even hit.

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We just saw it spiral down and crash.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It landed between the tank and us, on a little piece of high ground.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: How far away?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Five hundred meters. The Huey loses altitude fast, the tail rotor dead. It crashes.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She hit hard.

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Real hard. Surprised anyone survived. It takes a lot of time for the dust to settle.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: SERLING, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did the Huey at any time climb to an altitude to radio in a position?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLT
dialogues.text: They didn't have a chance. They were taking fire all the time.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: They could have climbed to escape the fire.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Roger that, sir, and left us to take the flak. As long as they were firing at the Huey they weren't shooting at us.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: The sun set shortly after the Huey crashed. Was there any more ground fire?

dialogues.speaker: LT. CHELLI
dialogues.text: The tank was incapacitated -- but we caught sporadic ground fire through the night. The Huey took most of it. It was between us and the enemy so...

dialogues.speaker: SERLING

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Major Teegarden, Nat Serling. I'm doing the follow through on your Medal of Honor recommendation for Captain Walden.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: Really? About time. Gladtomeetcha. This is Captain Cousins. What took you so long?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I work at the Pentagon.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: "Nuff said. Coke? Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Coffee'd be nice. Black. Can you break down the events of 26, 27 February, '91 for me?

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: Sure thing. I'm on call if that's okay. Let's see. I sent out Dust Off Two, Warrant Officer Fowler, at about 10:20 hours to evac the troop from that vehicular accident. We were getting ready to move forward, provide support for elements of the 82nd Airborne and the 24th Mech.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: A routine run.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: Well, kinda routine. We were in Iraq by then. Captain Fowler couldn't fly above 100 feet, that was our ceiling. So the fly boys could go low for their bombing runs. Our radios lost contact below 250, 300. So we were deaf. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 38.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And there was the dust and then the smoke from Kuwait, oil fields burning. Visibility was nil. So we were blind, too. And sand everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINS
dialogues.text: Sand storms, sand devils, sand outs! Sand in the rotor, sand in the fuel, sand in the intakes. Sand in your eyes, sand in your nose, your ears, your food, your water, your mouth, up your ass, in places you didn't know you had places. I'm still finding sand and I've been home for years. Sorry. He is embarrassed and goes back to his Gameboy.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: When did you realize Fowler's ship might be in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: Well, you sort of know how long a mission takes, how long enroute, the pick up, how long to the MASH, how long to return. I give âem some leeway. I gave Fowler almost an hour. Then I called HQ. They confirmed the pick up. Then I got the MASH unit on the horn and found out Fowler hadn't delivered. I wasn't that worried. A sandstorm could have put 'em down. He looks at Cousins.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINS
dialogues.text: Sometimes the visibility was so bad you set down to wait it out. They usually blew over.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: But I called Air Rescue anyway. The SP/5 comes in.

dialogues.speaker: SP/5
dialogues.text: Major, we have a possible heat exhaustion on the small arms range.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 39.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: How did Captain Walden get involved in the search?

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: She came to me. The Blackhawk takes off outside. Teegarden watches it go.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: When she first came to the unit, Walden rode co-pilot with Fowler during her orientation. They were friends. They'd traded envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Traded envelopes?

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: When we first got there, on the way over actually, we each wrote a letter to whoever ... in case we didn't come back. We didn't know what we were getting into. Saddam's crack army, best in the world, in continuous control for years. We were ... green. So we wrote these letters and traded them. You know, in case anything happens to me send this to my folks, my wife... I actually found Captain Walden's letter in Fowler's footlocker when we packed his ... effects. I sent it to her folks.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Captain Walden and Fowler were close.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: No closer than anyone else. No romance or anything, if that's what you're implying.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 40.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: (angry) ; Yes, we're Medevac. Rescue is our business, too.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I'm not questioning your decision, Major. So she went.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: Not right away. I made her wait an hour in case Rescue came up with something. Then I said okay. I made her strap on the extra fuel pods. She was not to attempt evacuation. There were too many on Fowler's Blackhawk for the Huey anyway. Walden's mission was to spot Dust Off Two, go for altitude to call in the location, then render what aid they could until the rescue team arrived. Those were my orders. SP/5 comes in.

dialogues.text: Sir, Medevac at Saint Mare Elyse. Bee sting.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 41.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN

Some kind of silly business to confuse the enemy. I used to tell Fowler that personally I thought he was confused but... Finally I told Karen, Captain Walden, she could fly.

dialogues.text: Finally...?

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: You feeling some reservations about your decision? Teegarden turns to look back at Serling. They are flying over the base, Serling trying not to look down.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: What the hell does that have to do with the action of Captain Walden on 26 - 27 February '91?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: None. I just... Did you have any contact with Captain Walden after she left your base camp?

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: We lost contact after she was twenty minutes out or so. She was keeping low, like I said, our ceiling was down to give the jets a lower profile. She put down once because a dust storm degraded visibility...

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: You learned this on the radio?

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: No. That I learned after the action.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Please stay with what you personally witnessed. I'll be interviewing the crew later. Why did you send along Specialist Altameyer and the machine gun? Isn't that unusual for a Medevac?

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: Well... There'd been reports of aircraft taking ground fire along the Euphrates. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN, (CONT'D)

Plus, Walden's mission was not to evacuate, but to locate and report. There was an MP unit next door to our base camp. Altameyer was always hanging around the company area. He had a hard-on for choppers.

dialogues.speaker: CREW CHIEF
dialogues.text: Don't we all? Teegarden smiles at his Crew Chief. They are over the are A ground soldier guides them in for the landing. The Medi bails and runs to where a group of soldiers circle a pron man.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN

Most of them get knocked down to the Silver Star or an Air Medal, but... I wanted everybody to know how extraordinarily this soldier had performed. They land at the hospital. Doctors and nurses are waiting on the pad. They hustle the patient into the Emergency Ro The Medic goes with them.

dialogues.text: Why did she do it?  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 46.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: And watch that tank chew up Fowler and his crew -- the patients. People were in trouble. We help people in trouble. It's our job.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Would any of your other pilots have done the same?

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: I don't know. Would I? I don't know. I hope so. I'd hope we all have in us whatever Captain Walden found that day. But... "Was shea hot dog?" "Was she Audie Murphy?" "why did she do it?" What does this have to do with the citation?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just curious.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: Same here. Same here. The Medic comes back with five Dr. Peppers. He tosses one to each of the men. They all drink - except for Serling.

dialogues.text: You put Altameyer, Ilario and Monfriez for the Silver Star and Air Medal.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: Yes, and they deserved it. They received them.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 47.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Good men?

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN

I had no reason to deny it. After what they'd done it was the least I could do. The least. They land at the airstrip. Teegarden shuts the Huey down.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Thanks, Major. I might call you back with some follow ups.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: She gonna get it? The Medal of Honor?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Just a matter of rubber stamping the paperwork as far as I can see.

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: Good. The helicopter is still. They walk back to the quonset hu

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: So you've got no room to cast any doubt on the actions of Captain Walden and her crew or me, for that matter. Not one bit.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING

dialogues.text: I'd rather we talk someplace quiet.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: I'm doing the talking. You want to hear it, sir, you'll have to be in my car. Serling hesitates, then follows Altameyer to his car. The get into the Saleen Mustang. Altameyer drives off the Pos

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Might lose my gig with the Rangers. C.0.'s pissed at me. Probably send me to the regular Infantry. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 110.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's okay. Let him. Infantry man. It's not a career, it'sa shitty job. When you join up do they tell you in the job description that you're supposed to kill people? I mean, you'd think that's a given, but... He takes a bottle of liquor from under the passenger seat uncaps it, He offers He laughs. takes a big swig.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Don't give me any shit about drinking and driving, sir. I'm not in the mood. Have some. the bottle to Serling.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: No, thanks, I'm trying to quit.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Me. Too, after this bottle.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: You have something to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Roger that, sir, 'deed I do, sir. Soon as I figure out what it is I will relay that information. You ever kill anyone, sir?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: You know, you can talk about killing somebody. Wolf talk, you know. "I'll kill you motherfucker, I'll waste your ugly ass." We all say it. But killing somebody... it's a hard thing to do. Easy to pull the trigger. Hard to live with. Know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I know exactly. He empties the bottle, tosses it out the window.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 111. He laughs, Altameyer

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: I killed people that day. That night. Out in the desert. I don't remember much about them. Little figures falling over. I sawa couple of faces, but none stayed. A dude with a mustache, I can remember him if I try. But Captain Walden's face. Her face... she's looking at me whenever I close my eyes. Nothing gets rid of her. Dope, booze ... praying. Even tried that. Nothing works.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Are you telling me you...

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: I'm telling you shit. Just shut the fuck up and listen... sir. but it doesn't work. This is a tortured man.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: It's the grey areas that get you. You know, right or wrong, black and white... Who'd ever think killing would be a grey area. It's wrong to kill someone. That's one of the black and whites, one of the Ten Commandments. Then you get in the Army. You kill people. It's part of the job, they say. You kill someone, the Army says it's okay -- then it's okay. Maybe that makes it okay for them, but it don't make it okay for you. Know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I think so. looks at him, desperate for help.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Tell me, sir, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: It's a struggle every day, finding out what's right or wrong. Most people don't even want to wade into those waters. That's why we have religion, Codes of Conduct, to sort it out for us.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 112.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: But they don't help a bit when it cuts to the bone, do they?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Well... they... No. What does this have to do with Captain Walden?

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Everything. Everything. He reaches under his seat, pulls out a .45, aims it at Serling! Serling stiffens. There is nowhere to go. He looks. They are speeding down a rural road. A train runs parallel to them. Altameyer punches it, passing the train

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: I always liked trains. Since I was a kid. They're big, black, strong, tough. Iron. If I ever boxed pro, I was going to call myself Howard "Night Train" Altameyer. What do you think Colonel, don't that have a nice ring to it? "Night Train". He is ahead of the train, makes a turn, comes up to the tracks, stops on the tracks. Serling can see the train coming, light on. Serling's hand goes to the door handle. Altameyer pokes the gun into Serling's chest.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Altameyer.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Shut up! Sir... The train sounds the whistle, rushing at them.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: I do love trains. Ain't that whistle pretty? Listen to it. It sounds again. The train is closer.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: But the train off track ain't worth shit. It's just ... scrap iron. He pulls the gun away. The train is roaring at them.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: I lost my tracks, sir. There in that desert. Get out.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 113.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Altameyer...

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT
dialogues.text: Serling gets out. Altameyer turns the car, faces the onco train. Serling grabs Altameyer's door. Altameyer floors it. The Saleen Mustang kicks in the turbo. Serling is tor loose. The Saleen rushes at the train. The whistle sounds Then they meet. A horrendous crash! The Saleen disintegrates! Explodes! Serling has to run to get out of the way of the flying wreckage. The train slows as best it can with a loud screeching and hiss. Serling can only stare sadly at the mess left of Altameyer and his car.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MP STATION, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Serling, very tired, is on the phone in the MP headquarte a police station with fatigues.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Well, sir, I'd like you to call the Fort San Houston Provost Marshall and have them detain Specialist Ilario. (beat) Substance abuse, trafficking. (beat) I don't know if they'll stick. I don't care. I just want them to hold him. (beat ) I think there's grounds, yes, sir. (beat ) Just hold him. I'm on my way. (beat) Thank you, sir. I'll call you from Texas. Sorry for the late hour. He hangs up, turns to an MP.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I need a ride to my car.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FORT SAM HOUSTON, DAY
dialogues.text: Serling drives onto the Post.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 114.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BARRACKS, DAY
dialogues.text: Serling stands in front of a room where two MP's are stationed. A First Lieutenant briefs him.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: We found a whole drugstore in his foot locker, plus drug paraphernalia, needles and such in every little cubby hole. Likea packrat with a Jones.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: But no Ilario.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Not hide nor hair. But we're on the lookout. So are the San Antonio Police. Serling nods. He goes out.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: How long are those souvenir shops open at the Alamo? I have to get some T-shirts for my kids. I... uh forgot last time I was here. I'll be back at say, 1800 hours. Your office?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Fine. See you then, Colonel. Maybe we'll have something by then.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Let's hope so.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FORT SAM HOUSTON, DAY
dialogues.text: Serling leaves the Post, in the heart of urban San Antoni A car just outside the gate pulls in behind Serling. It follows him into downtown. It is Ilario.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serling parks in a public parking structure. Ilario parks on the street. He goes to a pay phone, dials, talks. Serl comes out of the garage. Ilario hangs up, follows.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 115.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE ALAMO, DAY
dialogues.text: Serling stands in front of the Alamo again, bag of T-shir in hand. He looks down. At his feet is a brass plaque. The line that Colonel Travis drew in the sand.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The line between the heroes and the cowards. Serling turns to look at Ilario.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: A pretty thin line. I wonder how many "heroes" didn't cross it because they were more afraid of being called a coward than they were scared of dying.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I was just thinking the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Wanna talk? Serling nods.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: This way. Ilario leads him away.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: You turned me in. How'd you know?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: The sad fact is, if you command in today's Army you have to keep an eye out for all kinds of substance abuse. What are you using? Morphine?

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Anything. Anything to kill the pain. He is taking Serling to the river. They find a seat ona riverfront bench. This is the San Antonio River walk, whe the river cuts through the center of downtown, a walkway each side, trees over hanging the water -- stores, restaurants, hotels lining the walk. Dark, secluded, peaceful.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 116.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: I want to tell you what happened to Captain Walden.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Let me make a phone call. Some people are expecting me at eighteen hundred hours.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: No phone call. I do this now or not at all. You just might call the MP's on my ass.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Okay, talk.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: What time is it? Serling looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASE CAMP, SAUDI ARABIA, DAY
dialogues.text: Walden looks at her watch, then the sky. There is desert far as you can see, a few Army tanks, MP's, a few trucks. little olive drab oasis.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: I'm going to check with Teegarden again. Rady, Monfriez, Ilario and Altameyer play cards on the de of the Huey. Rady waits for Walden to be out of earshot.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: Leave it alone, will you? It's not our mission. She's going to put us in a world of hurt with this gung-ho shit.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: You're in a world of hurt unless you start paying attention to your cards. Captain W's okay. Takes care of her ship.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: And her crew.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: And her crew. Our job is to help people, remember.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 117.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: They call and say Fowler needs a Medevac, I'm there. It's not our mission to wander around No Man's Land looking for trouble. Raise.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: You got trouble right here. Raise you, five.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: If it was you out there, you'd want every aircraft in the hemisphere out looking. Pass. Walden comes back.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: We're on. Let's get in the air. Altameyer, Major Teegarden wants to see you. Altameyer looks worried. Rady tosses down his cards, with lot more force than needed.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: Walden's Huey takes off. Teegarden watches until the dust obliterates his view.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: The sand swirls around the parked Huey. Inside the helico the crew wait it out.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: I say we go back. This beer can with a rotor can't take much more of this sandblasting.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: Maybe this isn't one of your precious Blackhawks, but she'll do the job. When the last Blackhawk is towed to the junkyard, the crew will fly home in a Huey.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: We'll wait for it to blow over, then try a few more clicks up the river.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 118.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: But all this sand in the intakes...

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Monfriez?

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: She's fine, Captain. It ain't healthy, but it ain't going to kill her.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: What about the rotor blades?

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Rady, shut up.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: You don't have to prove you've got more balls than a man to make Major.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Rady, goddamnit.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: I'm asking for a transfer out soon as we get back.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: What, Christmas comes early this year? Looks like it's clearing. Let's get. I've got sand in places I didn't know I had places. They crank up.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: They fly.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: What's that? The main rotor sounds funny.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Now you're the Crew chief, Rady? The Crew Chief says we're air worthy. The Crew Chief is the final word on that. Now I told you to shut up. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 119.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you don't keep your conversation limited to the requirements of keeping this craft in the air I will haul your ass up for a Court Martial and you won't need a transfer. Ilario and Monfriez share a conspirational smile. Chalk o up for the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: The Huey flies along the river. Altameyer is watching out one door, Monfriez the other, both searching the river ba Ilario searches over Altameyer's shoulder, talking to him

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Both Captain Walden and I flew with Fowler at Hood. Captain "Ww" was the co-pilot, I was the Medic. When Captain "W" got her bird she took me with her.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Ilario's the only one who can treat my sinus allergies.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Local bee honey.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: The Huey comes around the bend and upon the crashed Black Men can be seen in the rubble firing weapons.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: You see Fowler?! What are they shooting at?! BOOM! The enemy tank fires! Ilario's question is answered The tail of the Blackhawk is blown off!

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Altameyer, there's your target! She banks the chopper. Altameyer fires. The bullets do little damage. Altameyer, adrenaline pumping, keeps firing after they pass the tank  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Cease fire! Cease fire! I'll try another run.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: We should go for altitude! Call Air Rescue! Get the fuck outta here! Walden banks the Huey, gets ready for another run.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: We'll make another try. Rady get on the horn to the AWACs, give 'em our coordinates! Here you go, Altameyer. They pass again. Altameyer fires. MIlario is scared. 120. Holes are appearing in the Huey. He stares at one near his head transfixed in fear. Rady is staring out his window.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: That didn't do shit. You might as will piss on a rock.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Rady, get on the phone! Monfriez, status? L

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: Stable. Nothing prime. Rady's right, Cap, we'd need a jet with a two-ton bomb to take out that tank.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: We're not a jet, but we've got a couple of bombs. Monfriez, unstrap the spare fuel pods! Altameyer, get the flare gun.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: What? What do you think are, Walden, a jet jockey? Go get a fucking Cobra! This is not our mission! BOOM! The tank fires again!

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Rady, just get on the phone to the AWACS. We don't stop that tank there won't be anything left to rescue! Let me know, Monfriez.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 121.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: Ready, Cap! Not quite, he's still fumbling with the straps. Altameyer is scrambling to load the flare gun. Ilario is braced in his seat, frozen in fear.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: One more time, gentlemen. I know you can do it.

dialogues.speaker: RADY
dialogues.text: We need that fuel to get back!

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: We've got more than enough to return, Rady. Get on the radio. Call in our position. That's an order. Here we go. She banks over the tank. Monfriez drops the fuel pod. It hits. Altameyer fires the flare gun! The tank bursts into flame. Ground fire rakes the Huey. The chopper goes out o control. It whirls! Rady screams! There's blood on his window. Ilario hugs the wall. Walden tries to get control

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Mayday! Mayday! Dust Off Three 1S...

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: Ilario bends over Rady, who has been hauled into the back the chopper. He presses a flap of scalp back over the shi skull, wipes the blood from Rady's face. Ilario is calm - this is what he knows how to do and he takes comfort in i Walden is on the radio, clicking through the channels. Altameyer blazes away with the 240 out one door. Next to him, Monfriez does the same with the M-16.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: We gotta get out of here. There's hundreds of them! We can't fight this!

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: One lung, through and through. Filling with blood, fast.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Call for help! Call for help!

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Radio's dead.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: The Blackhawk! They have more men! More firepower! We'll be safe there.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Bad scalp wound. Into the brain. Concussion at least.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: Yeah, the Blackhawk! We'll be safe there! Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Ilario, can we move him?

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: I wouldn't. He's barely maintaining as it is.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Monfriez, go to the other door! We're taking fire there. He obeys.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: I'll lay covering fire! Get to those rocks! Then you do the same for me!

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: We're not leaving Rady.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: He wouldn't make it. Altameyer, conserve ammo. We might be here a while.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: We gotta get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: We're not going anywhere. 122.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: We can't fight. We don't have...

dialogues.speaker: TAKE YOUR POSITIONS
dialogues.text: They do.
Ilario stares out at the night, scared, every noise makes him jump. Altameyer is at one door, Monfriez the other. Walden, Beretta out, sits next to a bandaged Rady.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: You know at dawn we're dead. They'll have reinforcements. We have to get to the Blackhawk before first light.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: It's so dark you can't see your hand in front of your face. Now's the time to do it. Slip right by them.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: I told you, Rady can't be moved.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: Rady's dead. He'll never make it. You know that, I know that.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: You don't even like him. All he did was give you grief. Now you're going to die for the prick? I say we go.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: So do I. Ilario?

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: I just want to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: It's a majority.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: That would be great if this was a democracy -- but it isn't. We stay with Rady. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 124.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't like him, but he's one of mine. I wouldn't leave one of you behind. I won't leave him.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Maybe if we surrendered the rag heads would doctor him up. Walden looks at him, hard.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: No surrender.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: Ilario checks Rady's IV. Ilario's hands are trembling. He glances out into the night. Walden takes one of his hands in hers, smiles. He calms down a bit.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: I hear something out there, I tell you. I can't see it, but I hear it. They're closing in.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: Of course they are. What would you do? I say we make for the Blackhawk now.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: And I say we've heard enough of that shit. Now. Can it. Monfriez looks at her, fingers the M-16.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Maybe we should surrender. It's a mumble. The others ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: You don't have to go with us, Captain. We don't even need your permission. That gets Altameyer and Ilario's attention.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Give me the M-16, Monfriez. He looks at her. She raises the Beretta from her lap.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 125.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: You may run, but I'm not letting you take our firepower with you. She takes the M-16 from Monfriez.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Are you going to take my gun away, too? She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: If I have to.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: You just might.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: (softly) They might treat us okay. I can make a white flag.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: Give it back. She turns to face Monfriez. He has his Beretta aimed at her. That jerks Ilario back to reality.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Guys...

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: She's trying to get us killed. It's us or her. Who you with, Ilario?

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Cap... Rady's finished.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: That your expert opinion, Ilario? He'll never recover. If he was out in a field somewhere and we came to Medevac Rady, you'd body bag him? You'd leave him behind?

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Yes. It is word filled with shame, a blatant lie.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: At least he's ashamed to say it.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 126. She looks at Altameyer, who glares back. Then Ilario, who can't meet her eyes. Then back at Monfriez and the gun ai at her. Quickly she raises her pistol and fires! Monfriez fires back. Walden takes the bullet in her stomach. But her sho at Monfriez went past his shoulder. A ragged Iraqi falls top of Monfriez, a bullet in his face. Suddenly they are in a firefight. Altameyer and Monfriez fire into the dark. Muzzle flashes reveal the dozen enemy who have crept up on both sides of the Huey. Ilario crouches in a fetal position next to Rady, whimper in fear. Walden uses the M-16 and Beretta. Then it is over. Quiet. They all stare into the night. Nothing. Then they look back at each other. Walden bleeds from the stomach. She is in pain as she jerkily grabs a magazine from the floor and reloads the M-16, then her Beretta. Monfriez is reloading his Beretta.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: We gotta out of here. They'll try again. Give me the 16, Cap. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: You're wounded, ma'am. Give him the 16. We gotta go. We'll carry you. She aims the M-16 at Altameyer.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Give me the 240.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: You won't shoot.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: The mood I'm in right now, Altameyer, I'd empty a magazine into your hide, reload and do it all over again. He looks at her, the M-16 pointed at him, then her again hands over the 240.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Pistols, too.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 127. They hand over their pistols. Ilario, roused from his paralysis, moves to her with a bandage. She points the Beretta at him. He freezes.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: You're wounded, Cap.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: You're with them.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: What are you going to do, keep watch on us all night? You're hurt. You're tired. You won't last 'til first light. She doesn't answer, shifts her position, gasps from the p that shoots through her. Monfriez moves forward. She poin the Beretta at him.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: What if they attack again?

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: You'll get your weapons back.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: By the time you give 'em back it might be too late.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: It's already too late.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: You can't stay awake. You won't last to first light. She just stares at him, grimly determined. Ilario starts crying. For himself? For her? Hard to tell.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER

dialogues.speaker: ALTAMEYER
dialogues.text: Give me my gun for God's sake. Christ...

dialogues.text: What are you going to do, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Go! I'll cover for you! Altameyer and Monfriez hit the ground, crouching, ready t run to Teegarden's chopper. Walden begins firing the 240. Altameyer and Monfriez run. They are hit, go down, get up and continue. Walden empties the 240, grabs the M-16. Ila is still there.

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Go! Go!

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO

dialogues.speaker: WALDEN
dialogues.text: Two stretchers. Now go! He runs to Teegarden's Huey. Breakneck running, blind pan bullets kicking up rocks and dirt all around him. He gets to it. The Crew Chief hauls him aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monfriez is leaning across to shout to Teegarden.

dialogues.text: Walden and Rady are dead!

dialogues.speaker: TEEGARDEN
dialogues.text: Both dead?!

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SAN ANTONIO RIVER, NIGHT
dialogues.text: The street light flickers and comes on. Ilario stares at it, sitting on the bench. Serling, standing over him, loo at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: We talked. Monfriez said she would have Court Martialed us. Altameyer agreed. Who knows? She was probably killed by enemy fire before the jets came. Who knows?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: You really believe that?

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: No. And he weeps. Serling waits.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: I figured out what all those veterans have in common. Fear. They've all been scared as they will ever get. They've plumbed the bottom of fear. Petrified scared. Until your heart stops, your lungs can't get air, scared sick. And nothing can ever scare you like that again. You've seen yourself at your worst and so...

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I think you're right, Ilario.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I did something in Desert Storm. Everybody said I made the best decision I could at the moment. They thought that it was a tactical decision. But only I know that I made the, call out of fear. Sheer, stark naked fear for my own life. And I was wrong. Some men died. They can justify it all they want, but deep down inside I know I did what I did because I was just .. plain, simple scared. It's okay to be scared in combat. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SERLING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It makes sense. But when it overrides your duty -- you've crossed a line. We both crossed the same line, Specialist. Let's get you some help. He offers a hand to Ilario. Ilario takes it, selfconsciou rises. Looks at Serling's watch.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: You have to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Altameyer was supposed to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: So? He didn't.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So I'm here to finish the job. Serling turns. Monfriez stands there. CAR-15 with a homem silencer at his side.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: Good work, Ilario. I told you you'd find a way to keep him here.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: You're not going to kill him. The killing is done.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: No, it isn't. I'm not going to Leavenworth just because you couldn't hold your water. He raises the gun and points it at Serling. Ilario, steps between them.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: I won't let you. You'll have to kill me first.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Now I know what to do here... He is dazed.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: I'm going for help. He starts down the walkway, looking for an open door. Monfriez climbs out of the water. He still has the gun. H fires! Serling runs down the walkway alongside the river. Monfri pursues -- fires. Serling is hit. A bullet tears through his side. He falters. Monfriez comes running. Serling gathers his strength and runs to a building under construction. He staggers past the "No Trespassing" tape, knocks down the crude barrier.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BUILDING, NIGHT
dialogues.text: A maze of half-completed walls, rebar poking out everywhe half-connected plumbing, scattered stacks of pipe and cem bags. Serling runs in and ducks behind the cement bags. They erupt into grey dust as Monfriez shoots at him. Serling tosses a piece of pipe at Monfriez and runs. They play hide and seek in the maze. dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ
dialogues.text: Sorry it's only a one-gun salute, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO
dialogues.text: Shit. Serling looks around, desperate. On the floor, welding apparatus. Against the wall, a wheeled table for the electrician. They can hear Monfriez coming.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: C'mon guys. Take it like a man. Ilario slumps against the wall. Serling looks for a way out. There is none.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Like you did in the desert, Monfriez?

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I did what I had to do.

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: Because you were afraid.

dialogues.speaker: MONFRIEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I wanted to survive. Serling finds a wrench on the floor. A bigass monkey wren He hefts it in his hand. A weapon. He looks at Ilario, wh shakes his head sadly.

dialogues.text: What about taking care of your fellow soldier? He looks at the acetylene tank, goes to it and tries to l it. He can't. He looks at Ilario.

dialogues.text: That's all bullshit.

They put it on the cart.  Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org 134. Serling puts the cart in the middle of the corridor.

dialogues.text: It's what she would have done. She's the real thing.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIO

dialogues.speaker: SERLING
dialogues.text: The secret is to admit to the weakest part of ourselves, accept it and...

dialogues.speaker: SERLING

dialogues.text: She's still a hero. The rest of it would only muddy the waters. Let it rest. Two of the eyewitnesses died tragically. The third is in rehab. Let her have her medal. She more than deserves it. He opens the door to his house. Meredith sees him.
